thread.title: Investigation of blaze that killed two firefighters is expected to move slowly
thread.title_full: Investigation of blaze that killed two firefighters is expected to move slowly

author:
Brian Burnes 
bburnes@kcstar.com
title: Investigation of blaze that killed two firefighters is expected to move slowly
text:
Investigation of blaze that killed two firefighters is expected to move slowly 
About half of 45 investigators are from a federal response team 
Dog trained in sniffing accelerants is on site 
Investigators are interviewing apartment residents, business tenants, firefighters Federal investigators combed through the rubble Wednesday of the fatal fire where two firefighters were killed and two were injured Monday night when the east wall of the structure collapsed. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com A cadaver dog was part of the investigation Wednesday at the site of the fatal fire where two firefighters were killed and two were injured Monday night when the east wall of the structure collapsed. Although all residents have been accounted for, the dog was used in case an unknown person was killed in the fire. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Pumper 23 (foreground) and pumper 10 were at the scene with firefighters Wednesday morning as they continued to work on the building where two firefighters from those stations were killed Monday night. KansasCity ATF employees joined local firefighters Wednesday morning at the scene of the fatal fire Monday night that killed two firefighters. Keith Myers KansasCity Fire investigators, including Missouri search and rescue cadaver dogs trained in sniffing out accelerants, examine the debris field Wednesday to determine what sparked the blaze that killed two Kansas City firefighters Monday. They were part of a team of about 45 investigators, including federal ATF officials, working the Independence Avenue scene Wednesday. The presence of the dogs did not mean that investigators believe the fire had suspicious origins. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Fire investigators, including Missouri search and rescue cadaver dogs trained in sniffing out accelerants, examine the debris field Wednesday to determine what sparked the blaze that killed two Kansas City firefighters Monday. They were part of a team of about 45 investigators, including federal ATF officials, working the Independence Avenue scene Wednesday. The presence of the dogs did not mean that investigators believe the fire had suspicious origins. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Fire investigators examine the Independence Avenue debris field Wednesday to determine what sparked the blaze that killed two Kansas City firefighters Monday. They were part of a team of about 45 investigators working the scene Wednesday. More than half are members of a federal response team that specializes in investigating fire scenes. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Fire investigators examine the Independence Avenue debris field Wednesday to determine what sparked the blaze that killed two Kansas City firefighters Monday. They were part of a team of about 45 investigators working the scene Wednesday. More than half are members of a federal response team that specializes in investigating fire scenes. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com A large crane lifted two fire investigators over the Independence Avenue debris field Wednesday as investigators worked to determine what sparked the blaze that killed two Kansas City firefighters Monday. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Pumper 23 (foreground) and Pumper 10, the trucks from the Kansas City stations where two firefighters were killed Monday night, are on the scene with local firefighters as the investigation continued Wednesday into what sparked the blaze at the business on Independence Avenue and Prospect. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Pumper 23 (foreground) and Pumper 10, the trucks from the Kansas City stations where two firefighters were killed Monday night, are on the scene with local firefighters as the investigation continued Wednesday into what sparked the blaze at the business on Independence Avenue and Prospect. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Employees with the ATF join local firefighters Wednesday morning at the scene of the fatal fire Monday night where two firefighters were killed. They were part of a team of about 45 investigators working the Independence Avenue scene Wednesday. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com On Wednesday morning, firefighters continue to pour water on the scene of the fatal fire where two firefighters died Monday night. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com A Kansas City firefighter looked over the burned out remains of a building at Independence and Prospect avenues on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, where two firefighters died fighting a fire on Monday evening. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Firefighters dug through the east side of a burned out building on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, at Independence and Prospect avenues. Two firefighters were killed and two were injured when the east wall of the structure collapsed during a fire at the site on Monday evening. Allison Long along@kcstar.com The badge of Deputy Fire Chief James Garrett of the Kansas City Fire Department is covered with a black band on Tuesday, mourning the loss of two firefighters who died Monday night after a wall collapse during a fire at an apartment building. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com At a news conference on Tuesday, October 13, 2015, Kansas City Fired Department chief Paul Berardi talked about the two KCFD firefighters who died while fighting a large fire Monday night. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Kansas City firefighters were on the scene of the aftermath of a building fire Tuesday morning in the 2600 block of Independence Ave. Tuesday morning where two firefighters sustained fatal injuries fighting the fire on Monday night. The firefighters were searching on the east side of the structure where a wall collapsed, killing two firefighters and injuring two others, during the fire on Monday night. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Kansas City firefighters were on the scene of the aftermath of a building fire Tuesday morning in the 2600 block of Independence Ave. Tuesday morning where two firefighters sustained fatal injuries fighting the fire on Monday night in Kansas City, Mo. The firefighters were searching in the area near where the firefighters died after a burning building collapsed on them Monday night. Keith Myers kmyers@kcstar.com Here is the apartment building at 2608 Independence Ave. before Monday night's fire. Google Maps Street View Firefighters were dispatched to a building in the 2600 block of Independence Avenue about 7:30 p.m. and found the structure heavily damaged by smoke and flames. Two firefighters were killed and two hurt after a burning building collapsed on them, Kansas City fire officials said.
